title: Tiffany Unveils Its Ocean-Inspired High Jewelry Collection
Outfits of defiance: would you wear shoes made from rugs?
description: A ‘wear-once’ mentality and dirt-cheap offers have made fashion a leading pollutant. Can a new global ‘upcycling’ scheme change not only the industry, but how we think about dressing?In 1942, the British government’s Board of Trade launched a Make Do and Mend scheme. It was one of several campaigns encouraging the public to save resources during the second world war by learning basic sewing skills alongside taking on bigger projects such as remodelling men’s clothing into womenswear. Today, Fashion Revolution, a non-profit social enterprise founded in the wake of the 2013 Rana Plaza factory disaster in Bangladesh, is gearing up to launch its own Mend in Public Day. This weekend participants from all over the world will be able to join free local community classes to learn how to mend and stitch.However, this scheme is aimed at addressing not scarcity, but overconsumption. Continue reading...
author: Chloe Mac Donnell

title: Topshop to return to high street with outlets in other retailers’ stores
description: Fashion brand also relaunching stand-alone website as owner Asos reveals sales continue to slideTopshop is to return to the high street via other retailers’ stores, its owner Asos has announced as it played down the impact of rapidly changing tariffs and tax rules on its US sales.The UK online fashion specialist said it had already signed deals to sell Topshop clothing to a number of retail partners and was looking for more, but the first step to a more independent image for the brand would be the relaunch of a stand-alone Topshop.com website later this year. Continue reading...

author: Steph Saltzman

title: 7 Black-Owned Dress Brands To Step Into Spring The Right Way
description: Spring isn’t just about a change in weather—it’s about a shift in energy, in mood, and of course, in wardrobe. With each new season comes a fresh start, and when we discuss spring style, we’re not just talking about trends; we’re talking about legacy, creativity, identity and craftsmanship that speak louder than trends or logos.From Andrea Iyamah to Sergio Hudson, we’re highlighting seven Black-owned dress brands that aren’t just making clothes—they’re making bold statements. So if you're ready to step into this new season with softness, confidence, head-turning energy, and just the right amount of flex, trust us—these are the brands you want in your rotation.Andrea Iyamah’s pieces are always a vibe! This dress embodies a vibrant, flirty appeal with a touch of sophistication. Known for celebrating individuality, the brand’s designs speak to your unique self-expression. Celebrities like Meagan Good have even been spotted rocking the Nigerian designer’s creations.Andrea Iyamah ODI DRESS - DANDI PRINT, $, available at Andrea IyamahMerging classic with a contemporary edge, Sergio Hudson nails it with this white-collar, belted, pleated mini shirtdress. It's a versatile piece that you can spice up or jazz down — either way, you can't go wrong with how you rock it. Simple yet sophisticated, it's a winning look that deserves a top spot in your spring wardrobe. Sergio Hudson Belted Pleated Mini Shirtdress, $, available at Saks Fifth AvenueVersatility is the name of the game when it comes to a Pantora design. With sizes ranging from XX-Small to 4X-Large, the brand offers a variety of options for every body type. The clothes are not only colorful and fun but are also eye-catching pieces that will have you feeling confident and giving main character vibes.Pantora Pantora Women's Wanda Draped Asymmetrical Wrap Dress, $, available at AmazonIf you're looking for a dress that balances comfort and style, this Rib Polo Sweater Minidress by Honor the Gift checks every box. Depending on how you pair it, this piece offers multi-dimensional appeal, allowing you to effortlessly transition from day to night. Also, with NBA All-Star Russell Westbrook as the brand's creative director, the fashion-forward energy is no surprise. Honor The Gift Rib Polo Sweater Minidress, $, available at NordstromYou know what they say about the color green — it symbolizes new beginnings, growth and renewal. In other words, it definitely gives a seasonal glow up. This lightweight, effortlessly chic dress features a low halter back and a side split that adds just the right amount of edge and soft, feminine flair. Consider it a great addition to your closet must-haves.House of Harlow x REVOLVE Frederick Dress, $, available at RevolveThis exclusive piece from the Theophilio Capsule Collection for Amazon Luxury Stores is more than just a fashion statement. It's an ode to the designer's Jamaican roots. The dress fits true to size and is the kind of piece that channels effortless Caribbean cool, making it just as wearable as it is meaningful.Theophilio Rasta Printed Backless Mini Dress, $, available at AmazonThis simple, haltered, form-fitting Orire dress is perfect for a night out on the town, date night or cocktail hour. The Nigerian-based, eco-friendly brand offers something for everyone, including price points that cater to all budgets without compromising on quality. Orire Orire Women's June Dress, $, available at AmazonLike what you see? How about some more R29 goodness, right here?7 Haitian Beauty & Fashion Brands You Need To Know9 Black-Owned Brands To Upgrade Your Festival Fits16 Black-Owned Brands You Can Shop At Nordstrom
author: Dontaira Terrell

title: H&M x Magda Butrym’s “Dreamy, Romantic, Slavic” Collab Is Finally Here
description: H&M has been releasing exciting and showstopping designer collaborations for just over 20 years — the most recent collections being with Mugler, Paco Rabanne, and Rokh. The latest, however, marks a first for the brand: Partnering with a Polish designer, Magda Butrym, whom H&M creative advisor Ann-Sofie Johansson calls an “emerging icon.”The Silesia-born designer and 2018 LVMH-prize finalist — known for her “signature blend of femininity, boldness, and intricate craftsmanship” — is celebrating her brand’s 10-year anniversary with an H&M collection reinterpreting bestsellers like delicate 3D floral dresses and oversized structured coats, according to a press release. “It was great for me, as a designer, and my team to look back and see all the pieces that were loved by clients,” said Butrym at an H&M conference.Roses are at the heart of this collection, as Butrym sees them as a “symbol of womanhood: both soft and confident, delicate and independent, arresting and ever-growing.” How poetic. It’s also intended to be a “celebration of femininity in bloom,” which couldn’t be any more apparent through the blooming catsuits, headscarves, and mini dresses (which model Vittoria Cerreti gave us a taste of), as well as the rosette-covered bodysuits, gowns, and heels.   “I really see this collection as a chance to invite people into our world — and to celebrate femininity, and the flower,” said Butrym in the release.  “When I design, I always think about these three words: Dreamy, romantic, Slavic,” she added at the conference.While the collection has a classic and timeless appeal, it also maintains Butrym’s modern edge — aka the thing that’ll make you stand out (err, bloom) from the crowd. Think: rosette denim corsets, rose-printed tights, and hat-headscarf hybrids. So, whether you’re looking for meticulously tailored outerwear, a sweeping sequin gown, or cozy matching sets, the H&M x Magda Butrym collaboration has a mix of statement-making and casual styles that promise to elevate your spring outfit rotation. Click on to preview the H&M x Magda Butrym collection. Then come back here on April 24 to scoop up the sought-after designer pieces, which always (almost instantaneously!) sell out. All linked products are independently selected by our editors. If you purchase any of these products, we may earn a commission.For more can't-miss shopping stories delivered straight to your inbox, sign up for our Most Wanted newsletter.H&M x Magda ButrymShop title: Sneaker Hall Of Fame: Adidas Continental 80

author: Foday Kamara

title: Shop the Exact Outfits From "The White Lotus" Season 3 Plus Similar Vacation Looks
description: Plenty of "The White Lotus" spoilers are lurking below, FYI. Our eyes were glued to HBO's "The White Lotus" throughout Season 3 and the much-anticipated finale didn't disappoint. Apart from its completely unhinged plot twists, we were also fascinated by the show's stellar wardrobe choices, curated by costume designer Alex Bovaird. Staying at Thailand's grandiose Four Seasons Resort Koh Samui, the central characters master the perfect vacation aesthetic in very distinct ways. From Southern mom Victoria Ratliff's airy dresses to British millennial Chelsea's vibrant swimwear and Hollywood star Jaclyn's statement designer looks, there's a character on the island who embodies every approach to resortwear. What's more, all their looks are easily achievable - and you can shop similar pieces here. Ahead, you'll find items directly inspired by their outfits onscreen, including the choker Chelsea was spotted in, which contained a hidden clue about "The White Lotus" murder and Lochlan's viral alligator shirt. Then, keep scrolling for pieces that capture "The White Lotus" vibe, from tropical-inspired prints to vibrant crochet numbers you'll want to wear even after the show's hype dies down. Whether we're featuring pieces sourced from Cult Gaia or affordable must haves from Amazon, our guide will be sure to cure any seasonal depression you may be experiencing in between vacations. Keep scrolling to shop our top resortwear favorites inspired by "The White Lotus," whether you've booked a flight or not.
author: Naomi Parris

title: 2 Editors Put the Magda Butrym x H&M Collab to the Test - Here Are Our Honest Thoughts
description: Magda Butrym is bringing her signature rose motif to H&M with a collaboration of ready-to-wear, accessories, and jewelry, currently on sale at HM.com and in select stores. It features some of the key wardrobe staples H&M is known for - bomber jackets, mini dresses, fitted tops, one-pieces - all reimagined with Butrym's whimsical, romantic flair. Think a cocktail dress covered in roses to mimic a bouquet, clear sandals with floral heels, and a rose-print turtleneck-and-leggings set. As Magda Butrym is celebrating its 10-year anniversary this year, the H&M collab includes archival pieces which fans of the luxury brand will recognize. The beloved halter top, for example, is here with its iconic ruching and rose emblems featured on the bodice. "Each piece brings its own sense of Slavic romance, while paying homage to the history of our brand," the designer said in a press release. "I really see this collection as a chance to invite people into our world – and to celebrate femininity, and the flower." In the past, H&M collaborations have included such iconic brands as Mugler, Rabanne, and Brock Collection. Notably, this partnership marks the first time the retail behemoth has collaborated with a Polish designer. Ahead, read our editors' honest thoughts about the new collection - and keep scrolling to shop our favorite pieces from the Magda Butrym x H&M collab.
author: Jessica Andrews
